content: The Citation Success Index (CSI) is a metric for comparing the citation capacity of pairs of journals. It is defined as the probability that a random paper in one journal has more citations than a random paper in another journal, with 50% indicating that the two journals perform equally well [[3], 2017, T. Milojevic and Judit Bar-Ilanb]. Unlike the journal impact factor, the CSI depends on the broadness and shape of citation distributions. A study showed that the CSI is a relatively tight function of the ratio of impact factors of journals being compared and grows slowly as a function of the impact factor ratio [[3], 2017, T. Milojevic and Judit Bar-Ilanb]. Another study found that the lognormal distribution of citation counts is the reason for the relation between impact factors and the CSI [[1], 2018, Zhesi Shen and Jinshan Wu].
